J	Liu, CC; Ju, J; Ma, J; Zheng, YM; Jiang, L				Liu, Chengcheng; Ju, Jie; Ma, Jie; Zheng, Yongmei; Jiang, Lei			Directional Drop Transport Achieved on High-Temperature Anisotropic Wetting Surfaces	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							NANOSTRUCTURED SURFACES; MICROSTRUCTURED SURFACES; SILICON NANOWIRES; FOG COLLECTION; SPIDER SILKS; LEIDENFROST; WETTABILITY; RATCHET; TRANSITION	The surfaces of ambient-temperature superhydrophilic tilting silicon nanowires (TSNWs) exhibit an anisotropic wetting performance at high temperature and a deposited drop moves directionally on this surface. A vapor film forming beneath the drop after spreading reduces the surface friction and the heat transfer efficiency between the drop and the surface, so the drop moves with a constant speed and little mass loss. J	Woszczyna, M; Winter, A; Grothe, M; Willunat, A; Wundrack, S; Stosch, R; Weimann, T; Ahlers, F; Turchanin, A				Woszczyna, Miroslaw; Winter, Andreas; Grothe, Miriam; Willunat, Annika; Wundrack, Stefan; Stosch, Rainer; Weimann, Thomas; Ahlers, Franz; Turchanin, Andrey			All-Carbon Vertical van der Waals Heterostructures: Non-destructive Functionalization of Graphene for Electronic Applications	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							SELF-ASSEMBLED MONOLAYERS; CHEMICAL LITHOGRAPHY; NANOMEMBRANES; FABRICATION; SENSORS	Non-destructive chemical functionalization of graphene for applications in electronic devices (e.g., sensors or transducers) is achieved via assembly of carbon nano-membrane (CNM)/single-layer graphene (SLG) van der Waals heterostructures. The CNMs are 1 nm-thick, dielectric molecular sheets terminated with functional amino groups. The structure and performance of heterostructured field-effect transistors (FETs) are characterized by photoelectron/Raman spectroscopy and by electric transport measurements in vacuum, ambient conditions, and water. J	Hong, Y; Pourmand, M; Boriskina, SV; Reinhard, BM				Hong, Yan; Pourmand, Mahshid; Boriskina, Svetlana V.; Reinhard, Bjoern M.			Enhanced Light Focusing in Self-Assembled Optoplasmonic Clusters with Subwavelength Dimensions	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article						self-assembly; SERS; optical vortex; photonic-plasmonic resonances; magnetic field enhancement	WHISPERING-GALLERY MODES; PLASMONIC NANOSTRUCTURES; PHOTONIC MOLECULES; NANOPARTICLE; ARRAYS; NANOSCALE	Compact metallo-dielectric hybrid clusters with subwavelength dimensions are fabricated by template guided self-assembly. Elastic and inelastic scattering spectroscopy and electromagnetic simulations reveal that hybrid clusters comprising TiO2 nanoparticles on top of a cluster of strongly coupled gold nanoparticles harness synergistic electromagnetic interactions between the building blocks. This results in a boost of the peak electric field intensity and a redistribution of the field in the ambient medium. The complex phase landscape in the clusters features optical vortices that enhance the magnetic field. J	Knesting, KM; Hotchkiss, PJ; MacLeod, BA; Marder, SR; Ginger, DS				Knesting, Kristina M.; Hotchkiss, Peter J.; MacLeod, Bradley A.; Marder, Seth R.; Ginger, David S.			Spatially Modulating Interfacial Properties of Transparent Conductive Oxides: Patterning Work Function with Phosphonic Acid Self-Assembled Monolayers	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article						microcontact printing; organic photovoltaics; phosphonic acid; self-assembled monolayers; work function	INDIUM-TIN OXIDE; LIGHT-EMITTING-DIODES; PHASE-SEPARATION; HOLE-INJECTION; SURFACE; PERFORMANCE; MORPHOLOGY; ELECTROLUMINESCENCE; TRANSISTORS; ELECTRODES	The interface between an organic semiconductor and a transparent conducting oxide is crucial to the performance of organic optoelectronics. We use microcontact printing to pattern pentafluorobenzyl phosphonic acid self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) on indium tin oxide (ITO). We obtain high-fidelity patterns with sharply defined edges and with large work function contrast (comparable to that obtained from phosphonic acid SAMs deposited from solution). PDMS stamps were fabricated at the Nanotech User Facility at the University of Washington, a member of the National Nanotechnology Infrastructure network (NNIN) supported by the NSF with assistance from Paul Wallace. Cu2O Inverse Woodpile Photonic Crystals by Prism Holographic Lithography and Electrodeposition	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							BAND-GAP; TEMPLATES; FABRICATION; MICROFABRICATION; WAVELENGTHS; EMISSION	Copper(I) oxide (Cu2O) inverse woodpile structures with a complete photonic bandgap (PBG) at 765 nm are created by using single prism holographic lithography (HL) to form a polymeric template, followed by Cu2O electrodeposition and template removal. J	Han, N; Kim, SI; Yang, JD; Lee, K; Sohn, H; So, HM; Ahn, CW; Yoo, KH				Han, Nalae; Kim, Sung In; Yang, Jeong-Do; Lee, Kyumin; Sohn, Hyunchul; So, Hye-Mi; Ahn, Chi Won; Yoo, Kyung-Hwa			Phase-Change Memory in Bi2Te3 Nanowires	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							ELECTRODEPOSITION; NONVOLATILE	Bi2Te3 nanowires exhibit the phase-change memory switching behavior. The as-grown nanowire has a linear current-voltage curve and a crystalline structure. After switching to the high-resistance state with a voltage pulse, the crystalline phases are partially changed to amorphous phases. This indicates that a crystalline-amorphous phase change in Bi2Te3 nanowires can be induced by a voltage pulse. J	Pang, SP; Englert, JM; Tsao, HN; Hernandez, Y; Hirsch, A; Feng, XL; Mullen, K				Pang, Shuping; Englert, Jan M.; Tsao, Hoi Nok; Hernandez, Yenny; Hirsch, Andreas; Feng, Xinliang; Muellen, Klaus			Extrinsic Corrugation-Assisted Mechanical Exfoliation of Monolayer Graphene	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							FIELD-EFFECT TRANSISTORS; PATTERNED GRAPHENE; ATOMIC-STRUCTURE; FILMS; GRAPHITE; OXIDE; ELECTRODES	An extrinsic corrugation-assisted mechanical exfoliation process is introduced to fabricate ultralarge, patterned mono layer graphene on silicon substrates. This exfoliation method, without any contamination, offers not only an ideal alternative for the scalable deposition of monolayer graphene on silicon substrates, but also provides a promising basis for the construction of graphene-based integrated circuits. J	Bolink, HJ; Brine, H; Coronado, E; Sessolo, M				Bolink, Henk J.; Brine, Hicham; Coronado, Eugenio; Sessolo, Michele			Phosphorescent Hybrid Organic-Inorganic Light-Emitting Diodes	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							METAL-OXIDE; ELECTROLUMINESCENT DEVICES; CESIUM CARBONATE; EFFICIENCY; CATHODE	Competitive efficacy and power conversion efficiency (15 cd A(-1) and above 9 lm W(-1), respectively) are obtained for a hybrid organic inorganic light-emitting diode (HyLED) with air-stable metal oxides as electrodes. Optimizing the gap width of the electrodes gives an on/off ratio of up to 10000 at 1 mV bias. The high on/off ratio, low energy consumption, low cost, simple processing procedures, and high air stability of the photoswitches indicate bright prospects for them in organic optoelectronics. J	Reese, C; Roberts, ME; Parkin, SR; Bao, ZA				Reese, Colin; Roberts, Mark E.; Parkin, Sean R.; Bao, Zhenan			Tuning Crystalline Solid-State Order and Charge Transport via Building-Block Modification of Oligothiophenes	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							FIELD-EFFECT TRANSISTORS; THIN-FILM TRANSISTORS; PHYSICAL VAPOR GROWTH; CONJUGATED OLIGOMERS; PERFORMANCE; DESIGN	The packing structure of a series of oligothiophenes is tuned via terminal substitution (see figure). The structural changes dramatically alter intermolecular interactions and charge-transport properties, as measured by elastomeric single-crystal field-effect transistors. Electronic structure calculations reveal the sensitivity of the transport efficiency to orbital nodal alignment, as correlated to the observed trend in field-effect mobilities. J	Dumitrescu, I; Edgeworth, JP; Unwin, PR; Macpherson, JV				Dumitrescu, Ioana; Edgeworth, Jonathan P.; Unwin, Patrick R.; Macpherson, Julie V.			Ultrathin Carbon Nanotube Mat Electrodes for Enhanced Amperometric Detection	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							PLANE PYROLYTIC-GRAPHITE; ELECTROCHEMICAL PROPERTIES; CATECHOLS; OXIDATION; NETWORKS	A cCVD method for producing transparent, conducting carbon nanotube (CNT) mats of near complete surface coverage is described. Disk-shaped UMEs using the CNT mats reveal reversible electrochemistry for outer sphere redox species and remarkably low capacitance. CNT mat UMEs can be used for the electrochemical detection of dopamine at micromole concentrations in albumin solution, with no decrease in electrode performance even after extensive use. J	Li, QM; Lin, Y; Creighton, JR; Figiel, JJ; Wang, GT				Li, Qiming; Lin, Yong; Creighton, J. Randall; Figiel, Jeffrey J.; Wang, George T.			Nanowire-Templated Lateral Epitaxilal Growth of Low-Dislocation Density Nonpolar a-Plane GaN on r-Plane Sapphire	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							IN-SITU; NANOHETEROEPITAXY; HETEROEPITAXY; OVERGROWTH; REDUCTION; DEFECTS	Coalescence of a vertically aligned GaN nanowire array on r-plane sapphire, a technique called nanowire-templated lateral epitaxial growth, is used to grow low-dislocation density a-plane GaN. Side-Chain Degradation of Ultrapure pi-Conjugated Oligomers: Implications for Organic Electronics	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							OPTICAL-PROPERTIES; POLYFLUORENE; POLYMERS; PHOTODEGRADATION; STABILITY; PHOTOOXIDATION; AUTOXIDATION; MECHANISM; DIODES; OXYGEN	The degradation of two defect-free pi-conjugated oligomers and the participation of their solubilizing side chains in the process are studied in unprecedented detail. The detected intermediate products reveal a mechanism or successive shortening of alkyl and oligo(ethylene glycol) substituents. Reversible Immobilization onto PEG-based Emulsion-templated Porous Polymers by Co-assembly of Stimuli Responsive Polymers	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							SIDE-CHAIN POLYMERS; PROTEIN IMMOBILIZATION; CELL-CULTURE; ELASTIN; SUPPORTS; POLYMERIZATION; POLYHIPES; SURFACES; BEHAVIOR; ENZYME	Reversible immobilization onto the surface of highly porous polymers through the coassembly of stimuli-responsive polymers is explored (see figure). Elastin-based side-chain polymers (EBPs) are prepared by RAFT and attached to the surface of PEG-based emulsion-templated porous polymers, leading to a responsive surface capable of pH-controlled reversible immobilization. JAN 5	2009	21	1					55	59		10.1002/adma.200801986	http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/adma.200801986			5	Chemistry, Multidisciplinary; Chemistry, Physical; Nanoscience & Nanotechnology; Materials Science, Multidisciplinary; Physics, Applied; Physics, Condensed Matter	Science Citation Index Expanded (SCI-EXPANDED)	Chemistry; Science & Technology - Other Topics; Materials Science; Physics	396IV					2022-12-19	WOS:000262586300004
J	He, Q; Duan, L; Qi, W; Wang, KW; Cui, Y; Yan, XH; Li, JB				He, Qiang; Duan, Li; Qi, Wei; Wang, Kewei; Cui, Yue; Yan, Xuehai; Li, Junbai			Microcapsules containing a biomolecular motor for ATP biosynthesis	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							H+/ATP RATIO; SYNTHASE	Over the past two decades, advances in modern biology and nano-technology have enabled a rapid development in the design and building of biomimetic functional materials. ATP synthase is one of the most extensively studied molecular machines because it can be used as a rotary motor in the design of novel nanodevices and it can also continuously synthesize ATP in an artificial environment. A lot of research efforts have focused on assembling ATP synthase in biomimetic systems so that a complex cellular process can be constructed in a controllable manner. As we summarize here, layer-by-layer assembled micro-capsules have proved to be a suitable cellular mimetic structure, which can be applied for engineering active biomimetic systems with a cellular process. An added benefit is that these assembled microcapsules can be used as bioenergy containers and thus ATP supply on demand. Reversibility of the perovskite-to-fluorite phase transformation in lead-based thin and ultrathin films	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							X-RAY; GEL; FERROELECTRICITY; CRYSTALLIZATION; PZT; PYROCHLORE; NANOSCALE	As film thicknesses decrease below 50 nm, control of cation stoichiometry in Pb-based dielectrics becomes increasingly difficult, a problem that is exacerbated by interaction with technologically important Pt bottom electrodes. DEC 17	2007	19	24					4399	+		10.1002/adma.200700021	http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/adma.200700021			6	Chemistry, Multidisciplinary; Chemistry, Physical; Nanoscience & Nanotechnology; Materials Science, Multidisciplinary; Physics, Applied; Physics, Condensed Matter	Science Citation Index Expanded (SCI-EXPANDED)	Chemistry; Science & Technology - Other Topics; Materials Science; Physics	253II					2022-12-19	WOS:000252511500018
J	Chia, PJ; Chua, LL; Sivaramakrishnan, S; Zhuo, JM; Zhao, LH; Sim, WS; Yeo, YC; Ho, PKH				Chia, Perq-Jon; Chua, Lay-Lay; Sivaramakrishnan, Sankaran; Zhuo, Jing-Mei; Zhao, Li-Hong; Sim, Wee-Sun; Yeo, Yee-Chia; Ho, Peter K-H.			Injection-induced De-doping in a conducting polymer during device operation: Asymmetry in the hole injection and extraction rates	ADVANCED MATERIALS			English	Article							LIGHT-EMITTING-DIODES; IN-SITU CONDUCTIVITY; PEDOT-PSS; ELECTRONIC-PROPERTIES; MAGNETIC-PROPERTIES; CONJUGATED POLYMER; POLY(3,4-ETHYLENEDIOXYTHIOPHENE); TRANSISTORS; MEMORY; POLYANILINE	A mechanism is described that can alter the doping level of conducting polymers during normal electrical injection, which arises from differential charge extraction/injection into transport sites, and which is likely to be an intrinsic feature of the hopping transport itself. This and not Joule heating is the cause of the conductance decay in PEDT:PSS at strong electrical injection, in which the polyelectrolyte counter-ion also plays a key role. Neutral (non-acidic) PEDT:PSS is more stable in this regard.
